name: magnolia-ncmx1-mercury™
wildlife-value: Seeds, which are high in fat, are a good energy source for migratory birds, squirrel, opossum, quail, turkey, mice & chipmunks. Pollinators, especially beetles, are attracted to the pollen which is high in protein.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: It is notable that magnolias are deer resistant.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Aggregate of dry, cylindrical, hairy, 3 – 5 inch-long carpels that turn red/red-brown with age. Each follicle contains one long bright red seed.
flower-description: Huge (up to 12"), showy, fragrant flowers that are red in bud and opening to bright lavender pink.
leaf-description: Simple, alternate and oval to elliptical. Pinnate venation. Very thick and leathery without teeth. A smooth, shiny intense green surface above and a fuzzy, cinnamon brown color below. Each leaf can remain on the tree for up to 2 years.
uses: The long-lasting leaves have been in holiday flower arrangements.  A variety of extracts taken from leaves, fruits, bark and wood have been used in pharmaceutical applications.
